line_1: And how would his audience their fortune bemoan,
line_2: If he gave them no sermons but what were his own!

line_1: Ah! long alas shall I bemoan,
line_2: FAREWEL! farewel! and art thou gone!

line_1: How often did the Bard thy Fate bemoan!
line_2: How often did he wish thy Pains his own!

line_1: Their loves like mine ill-fated I bemoan,
line_2: And in their tender sorrows read my own.

line_1: For how should I his trivial loss bemoan,
line_2: Who feel one, so much greater, of my own?

line_1: I ne'er the fancied ills bemoan,
line_2: No debts disturb me, but my own.

line_1: Long must thy friend his sudden loss bemoan;
line_2: And art thou, dear associate! art thou gone?

line_1: Oft seems some new misfortune to bemoan,
line_2: He sighs, and when he thinks himself alone,

line_1: Oft seems some new misfortune to bemoan,
line_2: In foreign accents, and a tongue unknown.

line_1: Too late their rashness they bemoan;
line_2: There sit, and now discreeter grown,

line_1: Blame not her silence, Warwick, but bemoan,
line_2: And judge, oh judge, my bosom by your own,

line_1: Mine with true sighs thy absence to bemoan,
line_2: And grave with faithful epitaphs thy stone.

line_1: "A husband and a father we bemoan,
line_2: "Long time I mourn'd — nor did I mourn alone —

line_1: The friend, the husband, father we bemoan!
line_2: Here that rich blossom dropp'd, scarce fairly blown;

line_1: Of all her Ills, wrong'd Angiers might bemoan,
line_2: He the chief Notice took, of this alone,

line_1: Of all her Ills, wrong'd Angiers might bemoan,
line_2: That she was branded mean, because unknown.

line_1: Whose heavy hearts the Publick loss bemoan,
line_2: To all both rich and Poor his worth was known,

line_1: Whose heavy hearts the Publick loss bemoan,
line_2: And cry, the good, the Generous Powlett's gone!

line_1: While the dear tender exile I bemoan;
line_2: Oh royal bride! oh daughter of a throne!

line_1: " In dolorous Mansion long you must bemoan
line_2: "For you (resum'd the Knight with sterner Tone)

line_1: " In dolorous Mansion long you must bemoan
line_2: "That Villain's Gifts will cost you many a Groan;

line_1: " In dolorous Mansion long you must bemoan
line_2: " Till, soft and pure as Infant-Goodness grown,

line_1: Nor Allen her loss shall bemoan!
line_2: Where her heart shall be cold as your own.

line_1: No longer shall the widow'd Land bemoan
line_2: A broken Lineage, and a doubtful Throne;

line_1: Go bleat — and your master bemoan;
line_2: His manners as mild as your own.

line_1: Ever sentenc'd to bemoan
line_2: Others failings in their own.

line_1: With throbbing Breasts Caelestia's Fate bemoan:
line_2: All that have pow'r to weep, or voice to groan,

line_1: While She, his Absence to bemoan,
line_2: The very Moment He was gone,
